text: one common kitchen conundrum is knife
skills one of the most challenging knife
skills to master is the julienne which
is a classic cooking school term for a
measurement of two to two and a half
inches by one-eighth of an inch and I'm
going to show you the classic way to do
that but I'm also going to show you a
shortcut typically you have to square
off the vegetable and trim off the
bottom the base end trim the side and
then you make eighth of an inch planks
of whatever the vegetable is you're
cutting I'm doing a carrot here today
and once you get a nice stack you again
cut a thin inch slices so there you have
it a classic julienne but when you
square off the vegetable you end up
wasting a lot of it and I'm going to
show you a simple technique that makes
this much faster and it's much easier to
sew carrots are notoriously tough when
you're cutting them into a julienne
because they're a rounded tapered shape
it makes them quite challenging but all
you need to do is slice on an extreme
bias so you're basically creating these
planks here but you're not squaring off
a vegetable you're not wasting eighth of
an inch slices again you can stack up
the carrots and then just rock through
creating nice thin Julianne's now
they're a little pointed at the base but
I think they actually look a lot
prettier so that took like what half the
time and what's really great about this
tip you can use it on so many different
vegetables cucumbers daikon radish
summer squash zucchini doesn't take much
work or skill but you're really left
with beautiful vegetables
and you didn't even need to go to
corners
hey guys thanks for watching do you have
a kitchen conundrum that you need solved
well if you do write in the comment
section below and as always click
Subscribe
